content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												The game itself tries to re-created the feel of everyone's favorite base-builder classic Dungeon Keeper 2.  How close does it come?  Closer than anyone else, but not without a lot of new, and very avoidable flaws. Much like DK2 the game revolves around you digging out multiple specialty rooms in your Evil Lair (Control Room, Armory, Barracks, etc.) to acomplish various tasks, and to keep your minions healed, happy, and armed.  The forces of good will also come wandering in to your lair in an effort to sabatoge your operation and must be kept at bay, or dealt with. You also have the option of building traps and security devices to keep intruders occupied, or dead... You have the option to deal with the do-gooders in various ways. By default your minions completely ignore all enemies and neutral tourists unless they are directly atttacked. You must "tag" an intruder on your island with an action for your minions to take. These are either "Kill", "Capture", or "Befuddle".  Killing is the most straightforward way, but the downside is that a dead enemy leaves a corpse behind. If tourists or enemy agents see these your "heat" level increases for that particular faction. A higher "heat" level for a faction means that they will send stronger agents to your island and are much harder to deal with. To deal with the bodies you must build a freezer and storage racks to hide the bodies until they decay. You can kill anyone that looks at you funny, but you will run out of storage space quick. Another method to deal with them is to "befuddle" them. You have social minions like Valets and Spin Doctors who will attempt to confuse enemy agents and tourists. Once their Mind stat is reduced to zero the enemy will stand there in a daze and do nothing. Agents only have a fixed amount of time they spend investigating your island, so the more time they spend drooling on themselves the less time they have to throw monkey wrenches in your plans.  The third option is to "capture". Minions will attempt to knock the victim out and then drag them to a holding cell. From there you can either kill them, or interrogate them. Interrogation is only useful against skilled civilians so that you can train your minions for that profession, otherwise it is a complete waste of time.One thing that sets the game apart from the DK series is the use of the world map.  Not only must you build and maintain your evil lair, but you must send your minions out into the world to Steal, Plot, and cause Mayhem to further your evil goals. It is a very unique addition, but has numerous flaws that make it more of a pain than a pleasure.  The world map is split between 4 different alliances, each alliance having 4 separate territories. Each territory has an income and a security rating. The income number shows how much your minions can steal from that territory, and the security rating determines how much heat your illicit activities will generate. You won't know what these numbers are unless you have a specific number of Control Panels in your control room properly staffed.  You also have access to various evil missions to send your minions on. These include kidnapping specialists for interrogation, stealing valuble loot, and regular story advancement mission.  THE FLAWS___________________________The game, unfortunately has many, many flaws that should have never happened.  For starters the controls are terrible and very unintuitive. Almost everything is done by right-clicking. Left is generally only used for selecting your Avatar/Henchman and to drag out room building templates.  What game uses the left button only 10% of the time?   The World Map controls are just as terrible.  Scroll speed depends on how fast your PC is, so old PCs have a reasonable scroll speed, but on newer ones you will constantly overshoot the place you are trying to scroll to.  This is very irritating when you are frantically trying to tell your minions to go in to hiding so they aren't caught by the investigator agents who randomly deploy across the world and kill your minions.  Speaking of which, when those agents deploy you have NO WARNING! While you are desperately trying to fend off agents invading your lair, about 80% of the places you have minions deployed on the world map will suddenly have an investigating agent deployed there as well, and if you don't luck up and check the world map at the right time all of your minions will end up dead after about 10 seconds.  The World Map button will sometimes tell you have have minions being killed, but by the time it tells you it's way too late.  Keeping enemies from casually wandering in to your base and investigating your freezer full of corpses, blowing generators up, or stealing gold is unreasonably difficult. As I mentioned before minions completely ignore enemies unless manually told to do something about them. There is no "default" action you can set for enemies so you have to manually assign an action for EVERY enemy individually. Good luck with that level of micro-management when you have two separate screens to pay attention to, neither of which can be automated in any helpful way.  Traps and Security Cameras are supposed to help with this but both are complete wastes of money.  Traps can only be triggered by an enemy activating a pressure plate, tripwire, or motion detector. The problem is that these can NOT be placed on the actual trap, they must be placed next to it (or anywhere else, but that is even less useful). When placed next to the trap the enemy will, 90% of the time stop on top of the triggering device while the trap gos off harmlessly next to them. If it does manage to trap an enemy it has an equal or better chance of trapping your minions as well!  Security cameras are just pointless. They are supposed to alert you to intruders and then deploy minions to deal with them. The cameras only alert if an enemy has been "tagged" previously. Enemies that havent been tagged will be ignored. Even if an alert is sounded only minions within earshot of a loudspeaker will be deployed.  All of these things are complete wastes of valuble cash. Dealing with enemies is needlessly difficuly as well. Enemy Agents will always be armed and you have the option of arming your minions, but only if you have built the proper gun cabinets, and only if your base is on Yellow or Red alert.  The rest of the time they return the guns to the armory and if enemy soldiers start raiding they will gun your helpless minions down before you can issue the alert. This makes some sense for your regular minions, but why aren't your guards armed 24/7? Your only real defense is your Henchmen, the only guys that you can manually control besides your avatar.  They can easily deal with weaker agents on their own, but require backup if faced with numerous opponents. You start with one, but can recruit more later on. One word of advice, avoid the ones that use explosives, they will kill your own guys more often than your enemies. The best method of dealing with potential intruders seems to be using the "befuddle" option if you have a lot of social minions. Yes, it requires 1 minion to be occupied with each target, but it saves freezer space and doesn't raise your heat level. Hotels are a complete joke. They are super-expensive, require staffing, and produce no income. Better off stuffing their corpses in the freezer. BOTTOM LINE_______________________A worthy attempt to recreate the magic of Dungeon Keeper. Some horrid flaws keep it from being a true successor, but it is well worth your time and money if you loved DK2.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2013
												A very fun game. think Dungeon Keeper, but where you play a james bond'esque villain where you try to take over the world. You get henchmen to buld your base, guard it and even fool turists to try and keep your activities unknown.Sadly there are only 2 levels, but with all the reasearch and the length of time missions can take this is a game you can play for hours on end with the many different traps and science devices you can strap agents too, uncluding a laser like the classic bond film, Gold Finger. One hell of a buy if you ask me :)A suggestion when playing this game is to alter the files so you can get more minions as I find 100 is too few, especially when you run into secret agents who can end up killing over 50 henchmen before collapsing and you can't get rid of them until you learn their secret weakness on the second level.Also I believe the research file needs to be fixed. Research on google to find out the fix.I've heard that there is meant to be a sequal in the works, but it's on the back-burner at the moment and I hope it doesn't become like DK3 where it became a mobile game instead. This is a really fun game that you can get many hours out of and with a lot of dungeon keeper like humor.

												Nice to see here. I spenr about 3 dollars to get this on steam even though I still have the CD's for it. It's just much nicer to be able to have it ready on download then search the house for the 2 CD's as well as as have a permanent funtional verison of the game. It is almost entirely functional on windows 10. You need to download some files to get it to work in 1080 and sometimes it doesn't work with steams overlay thing but otherwise it runs as well as it did before.As mentioned, it is a game simliar to that Dungeon Keeper game where you don't have direct control over your minion except the 2 or 3 main minions that you can collect. It's pretty much all AI controlled with you giving orders that you hope will be followed. You need to create a base that is difficult for enemies to penetrate so they can't rob you or kill all your doods. I would have to say that at least the pathfinding is pretty superb but the AI itself is a bit furstrating sometimes. There are certian things I wish they could fix to make the process smoother.  Would be nice if the social minions didn't stop escorting confused enemies out of the base just to confuse another enemy. The minions should know right away when a bed is occupied instead of walking cirlces around the beds to find an unoccupied one. Minions should be able to take turns when grabbing guns. Stuff like that that could of made the game is bit smoother.Overall the game has hours of distraction to it. I already played over 10 hours on steam except the overlay wasn't working when I played it so it didn't show the time played.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Evil Genius on of the first games I actually enjoyed playing back in the days. Manage your evil lair, send out your minions to various missions, defend yourself against hordes of cannon fodder agents or special agents, hire high ranking criminals to be your right hand man, be evil and execute a rebellious minion or a captured agent to raise moral of the troops.Playing the role of a evil character is really refreshing planning how to build your hideout with all the rooms you need and might need to set your evil plans in motion. Rasing your infamy to lure more high ranking criminals to your side. Research technology, weapons, rooms and traps for your lair. In this game you can fullfill your evil mastermind needs to the fullest.This game has a great community and as far as I can tell, most players actually fell in love with it and cry out for a second game which we sadly might never see in this generation. If you liked the real Dungeon Keepers franchise (not the latest fake one) then you might actually like Evil Genius or Banished both are going a similiar direction.I'd really love to tell you all about the game but I am wonderfully lazy. So treat yourself to a wine well matured and acquire this game one way or another, who knows maybe a friend has a cd somewhere with extra stuff on it. Or wait for a sale, your choice.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												This is probably on of the best base management sims ever created. Everything from the aesthetic of the game to the wacky voice-overs when you complete missions is charming and memorable. This is a game I regularly come back for not just for the excellent gameplay, but the metagame lore is just as enchanting(Mixer, anybody?).Pros- Constructing a base in any way you're interested in (corporate facade, death trap, hotel facade)- Those visuals dude, iirc TF2 took some inspiration from this game's art style- Quirky humor, but unexpected tidbits of brilliance- Valet minions sleep during 1-on-1 training and I find that unreasonably hilariousCons- Quirky controls when demolishing or fixing rooms (plan ahead plan ahead plan ahead)- World map agents automatically unhide after a too short interval (can be fixed in configs)- World map isn't really all too exciting when you only get 100 minions maximum without changing configs (reducing base defenses/activity)- Only 100 minions maximum..... unless you edit it to like 500 like I did :p$10 for one of the most memorable games is a steal, if you find it on sale for less don't second guess yourself... pick it up!

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												There are so few games where you can play as the evil villain, and this is one of them! You will build a base on a remote island and your ultimate goal is world domination. This game clearly took inspiration from james bond films and you have to manage your idiotic henchman to man your evil lair in addition to building traps to stop spies and other secret agents who would try to foil your schemes. You send out henchman and manage your base as you slowly accumulate more power and spread your evil reach across the globe. The difficulty will slowly ramp up as organizations dedicated to stopping evil doers start to take notice of you in addition to world governments. Are you cunning and evil enough to succeed despite all those good men who have stopped doing nothing?

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Get this game. It's great fun once you get the hang of it.tl'dr: Don't recruit Red Ivan."Even the penguins in alaska have a theory." "Penguins are in the south pole, Bill."Pros:+ Interrogate people with michael jackson dance moves+ Learn how to dance in nightclubs as demonstrated via in-game interrogations+ Interrogate people by placing them in a giant mixing bowl+ Interrogate people by crushing them between bookcases+ Hilarious and brilliant trap (defence) system+ Every item in-game becomes explosive upon destruction+ Can create an enormous obstacle course whereas you capture somebody, release them from custody and watch them attempt to traverse every trap you place in their way in hopes of escaping, only to have them captured upon reaching the front door+ Locker room building simulator+ Play hide and seek with your newly obtained loot because the game places your new loot in random rooms for you to discover+ Build a casino and kill civillians mid-game. House always wins.+ Allow the most petty of investigators to trawl through every inch of your base and hypothetically get an autograph from your evil genius, then let him leave willingly because nobody will believe anything he says anyway+ Can replace all beds with gym sets to achieve the same effect on minions+ Minions can literally live off saladCons:- Can't re-steal loot which is stolen from you- Concept of minion loyalty is difficult to grasp and manage- No notification to tell you when your men reach their destination on the world domination map- Marking every enemy for death, capture or weakening gets a bit monotonous- tl'dr: Red ivan is a knob. Red Ivan (red russian henchman/bodyguard) is very generous with his grenades and RPGs. Often using them indoors, which ultimately leads to the death of a lot of men and the combustion of a lot of rooms.- Having several super agents attacking your base at the exact same time can be very difficult to manage- Minions fall for traps in populated areas more often than enemies willCheat codes (that come in handy)type in HUMANZEE (TASK COMPLETE will pop up to show its active)ctrl C = give money in 100k increments (trust me youll want it)ctrl S = cause an explosion (spam it when super agents arrive on your base)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Oldie but Goldie. Picked it up relatively late (2015), but it seems to be all the fun it was back when it was released back in 2004. In many ways it reminds of the old James Bond movies, only that you play the villain. Gameplay wise it is a real time strategy, in which you build a lair into a mountain on a remote island. Then you recruit minions, expand your lair, research and upgrade technology, and last but not least deceive or eliminate visitors or enemy agents. You can also run missions in different parts of the world, granting you all sorts of rewards. Evil Genius is actually quite a complex game with many upgrades, research options, traps.. basically lots and lots of options to customize your lair and get expanding/researching. There is no fast forward, which makes sense considering your missions in the world are on a fixed timer, and your minions out there will get killed pretty fast if you don't check in on them occasionally. There are only two maps, although you will spend many, many hours on each of them. It's a slow game, but very rewarding if you take your time.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												Very slow paced game. I don't normally mind a game being slow paced, but this is just painfully slow.  After almost 24 hours on easy, I still haven't gotten past the fourth objective, or at least I think it was the fourth one. After setting up your base and getting things running, slowly, you have to collect plans for a doomsday device, which I assume you will later build. There are three of these devices, each one has three parts that you have to collect, so nine total. I can only find six, two of each. The objective says that you can find them on the world map through missions, which is how I got these six, by doing research on the map, which I have done on every place on the map and haven't found anything, or from Agents coming to your base. I have captured several Agents and Super Agents and tortured them several times, never find anything. I have no clue how you are supposed to get any of the remaining three doomsday plans, and there are no hints other than what is in the objective of "from the map missions, map research, from Agents."Another problem is that you constantly have enemy forces coming to your base and sabataging/ destroying everything they see. Even some of your own henchmen will do massive damage to your base when fighting the enemy. Trying to repair all of the damage and then build new things takes way too long and is very boring, preventing you from doing much of anything else.The only way to make money is to steal from countries on the world map, where your units are constantly being killed off and you then have to wait for more units to train. Something that really irritated me is that you can build a hotel and casino as a cover operation, which is expensive to get started, but you do not make any money from that. Those buildings are strictly to keep tourists out of your evil lair.I think 20 hours is more than enough to say I gave the game a try. It is almost fun, but they really did a terrible job on it.***Update***I put a few more hours into the game. The final 3 plans for the doomsday device were on random enemies, but none of the ones that were marked as "Agents" or "Super Agents." There is no identifying mark on the enemies that have the plans, you have to click on every single one to see if they are holding it, then kill them.So! plans gathered, 2 million dollars saved up as part of a mission objective, now to move to a bigger island. Yay! Except...When leaving your first island you must give the order for your minions to evacuate the island, with a warning that they will grab "as much as they can" (which apparently means "only artifacts"), and that once your Evil Genius arrives at one of the 2 ports anyone and anything left behind is lost. Naturally it sounds like your Evil Genius should wait in the base until everything is cleared out, so that's what I did. Bad choice.As soon as you sound the alarm 2 things happen: 1) your minions grab any artifacts that they can and move to one of 2 ports, and this cannot be stopped, altered, or overriden in any way.2) Enemyy forces swarm your base and begin killing your now defenseless minions, who will not fight back and cannot be ordered to do anything other than head straight into enemy fire on their way to the ports. Fun fact: there are 3 branches of training for your minions, with 3 levels of training. New minions can only be trained by other minions of a higher level in that branch. So if the enemy kills all of your high ranking military units, for example, then you cannot train any more of them on the next island until you go back through the tedious process of capturing more of that unit on the world map to learn their secrets.Following the warning not to send your Evil Genius to the port until the base was empty means that your Evil Genius is now completely defenseless and must hide from and evade the enemy swarm that now has free run of your base. This results in yet another long and tedius process.Now, provided that you made it you your new base alive, you may think you get to have fun and can avoid any logistical problems you had with your first base. No. Imagine a big triangle on this big new base of yours, each of the 3 points representing the 2 ports that your workers must go to to buy construction supplies, and the 3rd point being your treasury, where your workers must go to first to get the money to go to the port to buy the supplies. These 3 locations are as far from eachother as possible, resulting in a lot of unnessecary travel time to build anything. Also, you have no control over which port your workers go to, so when I built the entrance to my new base near the airport, my minions chose to travel to the seaport for supplies. It literally took over 5 minutes just to build the door to my base.Another "fun" thing here is that all of those valuable artifacts that you collected and transported from your first base are now sitting around outside, ready to be stolen by enemies, and there is nothing you can do to stop them because almost all of your minions were killed when trying to leave the first island.Long story short, it took over 2 hours to get my new base running, by which time several artifacts had been stolen and the last of my skilled mininos had been killed. I was out of money (apparently the 2 million was not enough, and I hadn't even built a lavish base, just the basics), and enemy units were all over the island because it took 2 hours to build. Essentially you are worse off than when you started the first island because back then the enemies were not coming after you as hard as they are now.Again, terrible game, do not buy it even if it is 90% off. Don't even waste your time if it is free.

KILL THIS TRAITOR!!!REAL REAL REVIEW:Ok, this is the real review this time. So, Evil Genuis, a game alot like Mastermind exceot the fact that it cost money and has alot more features and not to mention alot of more time that you will most likely be depositing into this masterpeice.Have you ever wanted to destroy the world? No? How about take over it? No? How about torture the people that inhabitate it because you can? NO?! ♥♥♥♥ it then, just become a god damn useless island where tourist come to see the sites. You can do all those things and more in this base building, strategy, world domination/tourist island/ torture island/ world destroyer simulator. The main goal that your supposed to fallow is to conqure the world in various ways. It can be very, VERY difficult to start out but you will surely handle the ropes right eventually. One thing to keep in mind while playing this, NEVER be too ambitious when it comes to building your base. I started out my first time by trying to completely fill up the mountain with as many rooms as possible, at first I ran super low on money and it ended up taking me 2 hours to get it a quarter way done, then secondly I had to take almost all of it down because I had unlocked other rooms I needed in the mountain. Oh yeah, forgot to mention that you build your base in a mountain. You can also build tiny houses outside of the mountain to build bases in, but be careful since tourist or spies can get easy access to them and report them to the country they came from. Ofcourse you could always just capture them before they leave and torture them  if you wish. Also, waiting is a huge factor in this game, but you can shorten the wait time by spending gold (which is in game money) to shorten it. Before you say anything about pay to win, keep in mind that this game is 1: not F2P and 2: has no micro transactions. If the government is becoming to hard to handle, or if you just wanna see something funny happen, set up traps in your base so the government forces will run into them when infaltrating your base. There's alot of stuff to do in this game that I haven't mentioned and all this talk about the game make me want to go back to playing again, so i'm off to take over the world!TL;DR?10/10, the best game I have EVER played. But I have a weird taste for games so you may or may not enjoy the game. Also, waiting is a huge factor if you wish to not spend much money (in game money ofcourse).

number of helpful: 8 of 26 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												I'm starting this review not knowing whether at the end I'll give it a thumbs up or a thumbs down - which pretty much tells you my thoughts.    Evil Genius is a 1960s style James Bond/ Man from Uncle/ Our Man Flint  version of the Bullfrog Dungeon Keeper games.    The game is split between a base mode where all of the animated action takes place and a world map where you carry out missions that are solely a matter of numbers - you commit the designated number of agents of various types to a mission and watch their figures fall by attrition until they either succeed in the mission or fail.    As all the action takes place on YOUR ISLAND and in YOUR BASE any bad failures mean large amounts of damage to your base and a long grind to rebuild.  That's a problem I'd echo from some of the other negative reviews.  Money is gained by allocating agents to steal on the map level.  Practically it meets clicking to add agents to a country to get money, and then clicking and moving them to a new country before enemy agents start turning up and killing them.  Agents regenerate only at one a minute unless you pay cash to regenerate faster which costs you cash obviously.  The basic mechanics are a bit of a grind.    There's also the problem that the game seems to be played on two very long levels.  So my entire game time has been on a single level.  There's no way to change base design part way through (although you can destroy individual rooms and replace them with a different room in the same size).  You can't cancel purchases.      Research isn't entirely intuitive.  I discovered after a long time you had to select both an item to research AND a piece of equipment for anything to happen.  Also hotels (used to distract tourists) didn't work for me.  The hotel wings never attached to the core so they were virtually useless.    You'll soon learn the value of your valets who do a prime job of distracting enemy agents.  Keep most of the incriminating stuff some way inside your base and even agents that get inside your base can be gently persuaded to leave (instead of killing them or capturing and torturing them) before discovering anything truly incriminating.    There's bizarre irritants too.  I did a mission wherein I stole a cloning machine all for it never to be assembled in my base for me to use.    Some of the game doesn't really hang together that well.  For example other than gaining new skills from specified targets capturing and interrogating (i.e. torturing to death) prisoners never seems to do much.   The main problem is the lack of variation in the game.  You stay on the same screens, you can see everything, enemy always enter by the same door (or doors if you add another entrance), you can't easily identify enemy (it flashes up but not easily).  There's not enough change, not enough development, and not enough fun things to do to make a really good game.    This is a great idea let down by some poor execution.  At the full price of £6.99 I wouldn't touch it but for anyone nostalgically missing Bullfrog's Theme Hospital and Dungeon Keeper games at 50% off and higher in the sale it will provide you with a few hours of fun.  Until you realise the next few hours will be exactly like the first few hours.S.x.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This game could have been very, very good. It has a very unique, well-presented concept : you get to play as a James Bond villain, complete with the stupid minions, eight-feet tall bodyguards and shark-filled traps. The art and concept teams did a great job, creating very interesting characters and buildings that makes you want to unlock everything and to find out what the game has to offer.The one problem this game has is its pace, and it's, sadly, a crippling issue. No matter how well optimized your base is, you will spend most of the game waiting endlessly for minions to be recruited, trained and outfitted so you can attempt missions. Those "missions" only require you to have the right number of henchmen, to click on a button and to wait (and hope) until the mission succeeds or fails. That's it. You don't get to do anything else, you don't get to command your soldiers as they attempt to steal a german satellite or whatever you sent them out to do. Clicking "Start mission" and waiting. That's all there is to this game besides base building and it's a little underwhelming. Then again, it would all work perfectly if you did not have to wait for dozens of minutes for your henchmen to be recruited and trained for missions. The worst part is that you always have to choose between waiting less or playing efficiently : recruiting minions faster costs money, so if you want to use your money carefully (and you will), you need to wait even longer. Same goes for your missions : you need to send henchmen away from your base so they can steal money... which makes your missions' progress even slower, because the henchmen you're using to steal money can't go on missions. There is no way to increase the game's speed either. It's like the developers really wanted the player to choose between waiting for long, unproductive minutes or to use his hard-earned funds to actually keep playing the game. It's not rewarding at all and makes the whole game feel like a grind.I have played about twenty hours because every once in a while, I tried giving the game another chance, reinstalled it and started another playthrough, only to get tired of it at the same point, after five or six hours, every time. It's just so terribly slow, so full of waiting and almost devoid of actual gameplay besides the base building that is also very, very slow once you spent your initial funds (because earning money in this game is also very slow and difficult). To me, Evil Genius will always be the game that could have been, and that never will be.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												You know, I really really wanted to like this game. I'm a huge fan of dungeon keeper, dwarf fortress, etc etc etc. I've heard nothing but good things about it.But after spending over 4 hours trying to finish the first map on the campaign, all I can say is that this game is atrocious. The pacing is absolutely terrible.Example: $100 per minion per minute basically means getting the funds so you can build a hallway takes roughly 10 minutes.The bugs are game stopping. For instance: Don't try to build a hotel too close to a depot. Your minions will never finish it, and it'll suck up all your money. And you can't cancel the construction.Your minions have self-defeating AI.For instance: I assigned my new valet minion to the training room, but he had low smarts from accidentally triggering a trap on the way over. Now, because the training room saps smarts (wtf?), he is stuck in an eternal loop there, and I can't train his replacement. Had to kidnap a whole new maid.The 'world domination screen' is frustrating.For instance: There's no timer or progress bar on how long it'll take for your minions to get shuffled around. "Not a big deal, I don't mind checking on it randomly. Can't wait to commit this act of infamy once all my guys are together!"<10 minutes of dealing with panicked tourists later>"Hmm, I wonder if those minions showed up yet --:<Minions there are already dead, because an agent already showed up & killed them without ever notifying you.>Even after exploiting the neutered enemy-heat of the first level of the campaign to build up all the money I'd ever need, I still struggled to get things done. I repeat -- money wasn't even an issue. I built up my base as best as I could without having everything unlocked, and amassed a small army of over 70 henchmen. Hours and hours later, I had still only commited a handful of acts of infamy due to all the subtle "features formerly known as bugs".

number of helpful: 1 of 17 people (6%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												Evil Genius is set in the cold-war era of 1960s superspies much like the NOLF games but, on this occasion, the player is on the side of evil megalomania rather than sexy crime fighter. The game involves building an impenetrable base on a secret island within which henchmen are trained, spies are tortured and doomsday devices are researched and developed. It is very much a Dungeon Keeper game in the NOLF world, but has the disadvantage of being overly-ambitious (much like the evil overlord you control). It can be very difficult to work out exactly what's going on, or how to defend your base, or where to deploy the wonderful new laser your scientists have researched... even with the glossary, tutorial, movies and online help! It looks like it could be an amazing game to get into, but I just found it too frustrating - I soon found myself struggling to make ends meet since I was constantly low on cash, and the only way to get cash was to risk my minions by sending them out into the big wide world, at which point the forces of good started killing them off... and I found myself low on cash and low on minions, and now the forces of good were sending squads of soldiers to blow up my base (in response to my minions' brief activity out in the big wide world) and I didn't have anyone left to defend it!It is beautifully presented and I would like to recommend it based on that and its promise, but it unfortunately failed to live up to my high expectations!

												I bought this on sale and I am glad I did not pay full price. It is very buggy and crashes frequently. The gameplay is simple and can get very repetitive however it does have the secret of "just one more quest" value to keep you going. The base requires constant supervision if you want to maintain you supply of minions and henchmen.The humour is weak, mostly dad jokes or plays on every old Bond film you have ever seen.The difficulty level spikes considerately when your  notoriety level increases making the game a grind of creating minions, protecting them and then losing them on a mission. Wash and repeat. Also frustratingly, the AI control of the minions is as dumb as mud. They constantly wander into your own traps and blindly run off on low priority tasks even after using your overlord to set a high priority on an urgent task.All in all I don't think this is a game to appeal to many but  I will complete it for my own satisfaction.Additional: I managed to complete the game after a few restarts despite the bugs. It has no replay value.In response to the comments about running an old game on a new PC I am runnning it on a PC I bought in 2006 and in Windows 7

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												I can't tell if this is the best bad game i've ever played, or the worst good game i've ever played.Evil Genius is one of a kind. You play as the typical James Bond villain, with 8 feet minions fighting for you as you forfill your dreams of world conquest. This concept could of worked, very well. But Evil Genius completely crushed this golden oppurtunity with terrible AI, and tedious grinding.One of the HUGEST problems with Evil Genius is the way your "Minions" work. In a game like this, you're supposed to feel like a badass, as you epicly fight through enemy soldiers with your loyal army of minions. But in Evil Genius, you don't feel like a badass, you feel like a victim. As soldiers wave through corpses of your minions while your remaining soldiers constantly desert you every 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes.The only way to keep up your minions "loyalty" is by interrogating enemy investigators/soldiers you captured. Which is extremely hard to do depending on the way you play. Minions drain on loyalty completely every 3 minutes, and depending on your heat trespassers barely ever show up.While their not busy constantly deserting, their busy going insane, getting stuck in a corner on a big piece of nothing as they suck up minion space.So then your last saving grace is a henchman, which you only get about 3 of in the time you play.Evil genius can be fun in the first couple hours, but it gets REALLY frustrating, REALLY fast.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on January 18, 2011 I really want to like Evil Genius. The Bond-villain style of the game is really fun and funny, and the idea of building your island lair up from scratch has some real appeal to it. But in the end this game simply is far too shallow and repetitive to be enjoyable in the long term.The art design is charming, and so are the animations and sounds, but the meat and potatoes of the gameplay simply loses its appeal far too quickly.The base building mechanics are solid and the traps are fun to build and use, but there is no differentiation between islands, and you are often restricted in the size of base you can build. Research can grant you more expensive but more space efficient versions of existing technology, but deleting old building plans within the confines of limited space and starting over is a real pain.The minion AI is atrocious, which I suppose is intentional, but it is also lazy developing. Your minions will constantly die in your own traps, and minions make no distinction between themselves as far as their role goes. Your ever so valuable third tier minions are just as likely to stumble into the gas pit attempting to kill an intruder in hand to hand combat and die as a plain worker is. I don't even want to start talking about how repetitive the evil missions are.These are just a sampling of the problems with the game. Overall, I would say it is a fun little game that is not worth more than a couple dollars.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												By no means a perfect game, but a deeply enjoyable one. The game focuses on base building and management, trying to keep the endless waves of agents from discovering your evil lair. The world missions almost seem supplementary to that, though they are needed to progress the game. You will find yourself waiting for these missions before you can progress. Many of the issues I believe would be worked out in a sequel, though rumours have been circulating for years whether this will happen. Personally I would love to play a sequel that captures the humourous spirit of the original with some of the edges smoothed off.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												I bought this the day it came out.  From an actual store, at full price -- I was that excited about it.You know Theme Hospital or ...well any of the Theme or Tycoon or similar games where you build a park/zoo/airport/factory/prison or whatever?  Take that, add a huge helping of James Bond (and any movie from that whole spy era) spoof, a lot of humor and plenty of developer love.You are building an underground evil lair, and you gotta make sure your minions have facilities to work, relax, train, rest, and research.  Of course you also need jails and interrogation machines for when you capture spies, and an elaborate trap system so agents and civilians don't get in, and don't forget room for a doomsday weapon.There are a few frustrating times when unfortunate timing results in the minion that was bringing an important item back from the helipad gets attacked by Jet Chan (lol!), and then others run to get the item to be slaughtered one by one.  But most of the time it is so awesome.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Since most people haven't heard of Dungeon Keeper, the next best comparasion would be the Sims. Like the Sims, your loyal minions have needs that must be met or they would collapse, die, or even run away. Building facilites in your base is very easy to pick up, as you progress throughout the game, you will have access to more efficient need-restoring objects but much of them bring along higher heat. What is heat? That's the stuff that agent investigators (a.k.a. the "good" guys) want to bring home to have a proper "clause" to send in even more dangerous agents to steal your money and loot, attack your minions, or simply blowing everything up. I don't recommended killing agents as another one would likely take his/her place shortly after, it's better to waste their time with any means possible.Also unlike the Sims, you are not in direct control of the majority of the characters in the game but rather interact with them mainly with objects.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												If you like Minecraft redstone projects, you'll love the trap construction concept. This little gem is something along the lines of SimCity bumping uglies with a James Bond movie. The graphics are simple, even a little plain, and the missions seem to bleed into each other, but the game is extremely cheap. Snatch it up on a summer/winter sale and enjoy the bargain pricing. As a helpful tip, get outdoor cameras and point them towards your base entrances. It saves so much time and effort when you hear enemy agents approaching. Also, Valets are your friend for keeping low level threats at bay.

Posted: November 1, 2011
												Word of advice: Yes, you'll need strategic and 'Dungeon Master-like' base building thinking... but above all you need PATIENCE and a lot of it. You'll wait to recruit and train minions to lose most of them on a mission (successful or not) or at the hand of enemy govt agents. So you'll have to recruit and train new minions, etc... So, a big part of this game is about waiting...That said, the building of your base, if done correctly, with the help of well trained and equiped minions and devious traps will keep civilians and enemy agents mostly away from the heart of your operations and is quite satisfactory...Building your 'Empire', via stolen money/loot gathering, scientific research, intelligence gathering, 'interrogation' of enemies, civilians or your own minions (for fun or keeping them in line), getting better and more powerful minions, getting more notoriety (giving access to better equipments), etc... is also well done.A good game to play the bad side of a James Bond's movie...

Posted: December 18, 2010
												Evil Genius is what happens when Dungeon Keeper and James Bond villains have a child together. You play, as the game's title says, an evil genius, bent on destroying the forces of good and conquering the whole world. You start off on a small island paradise, with only a handful of minions, 250,000 dollars, and a single henchmen. From there, your task is to build a complex base of operations into the mountainside,  complete with traps, training facilities, and more, while at the same time plundering riches and fighting off the constant intrusions from the forces of justice. Evil Genius manages to bring out the worst in all of us, and you'll be surprised to find yourself stalking the despised well-doers as they land on your little shred of land, eager to find out how they will meet your demise. And with ways ranging from bazooka-wielding Russians, to a complex set of bee-related traps, you'll find dozens of ways to amuse yourself with their death.

Posted: May 30, 2015
												The greatest Evil mastermind game ever made most likely.I played this game for hours and hours back when it was new.The game has a lot of humor and great characters.It has some very fun mechanics. Like building the ultimate trap rooms and watch as the Agents of the world tries to best your contraptions. And then do a truly evil laugh as they fail utterly.There is just something very special about being the Evil Genius and having minions to do your bidding in your quest for world domination.It's different and fun. And I have been waiting for Evil Genius 2 for years now. I really do hope somebody pics up this IP at some point and make a proper sequel.It's hard to express the joy of this game. But if you have ever wanted to be the Bond villain, then this game is your best bet.It does have a few flaws though. Quite a few actually.There is no widescreen support. But you can find a workaround for that if you google. "Evil Genius WSGF" The ui will be stretched though.Some of the mechanics are a bit annoying and requires more work then what should be necessary.There can also be a lot of down time while you wait for your minions to complete work orders. Or waiting for money to come in.There are more minor things that keeps irking me from time to time. But in the end the things that are good with the game far outweigh what is bad.If you are unsure about the game I would suggest watching some let's plays on youtube. I would also recommend not watching a whole lot of them if you want to avoid spoilers.There are some super agents that can only be defeated in a certain way. And some of the fun (and annoyance) in the game can come from defeating them. Until you can find that way to defeat them they will just keep coming back making your life hell.

Posted: June 11, 2015
												I don't know any other games that embrace the Spy genre with this much style. Everything about this game, from the music to the characters, is meant to fully immerse you into a world of minions and doomsday devices.The concept is simple. You are an average Bond villain, and you want to take over the world. In order to do so you need a base of operations (which you have to lay out and build yourself), an army of minions (who live in your base and are trained into better jobs there) and a control room that lets you send your minions across the globe to steal money for you and carry out devious schemes. But this attracts the attention of the 5 superpowers in the world, who will start sending investigators and agents to your base. As your global notoriety climbs, you have to manage your heat or you will become overwhelmed by the number of investigators and soldiers sent to  attack your base.The game is an incredible lot of fun to play. Although your first base design will inevitably suck, the more you play the better you will get at it. (Also, a minor spoiler: halfway through the game you move to a new base, which lets you fix any mistakes you may have made that playthrough... Only to make a bunch of new ones, of course.)But I also have two gripes. First of all, you can issue basic orders and give anyone on your island a tag that determines what must be done with them (jailed, dazed or killed), but you cannot directly control your minions. This is understandable - you ARE the mastermind, after all - but can get quite frustrating when all of your minions are busy and you really need something done. Fortunately you can directly control your henchmen, who may not be able to build or do much work around your base, but who are very good at killing, dazing or jailing intruders.Second of all... The game has a lot of bugs, and most of them are really minor and solved by the Unofficial Patch. Why no such patch was ever brought out officially is beyond me. There are also game breaking bugs: for example, once you place down the conference table in the first island, you may not move or delete it or your evil genius can no longer sit at it. This, of course, halts progression and gets you stuck.Fortunately these two problems are not extremely big, and have not ruined my fun yet. It's good to be an Evil Genius.

Posted: January 15, 2015
												A wonderful game that has aged well over the years. Unleash your inner Evil Mastermind as you build your island headquarters for your schemes and conduct missions all over the world against the forces of justice.A game I have put many hours into over the years when it first came out and glad to be playing it again, and while some of the graphics may not quite be up to standards of what some would expect today, it by no means looks horrific with the art style suiting the game perfectly. The music and menu screens add to the spy farce that this game plays to heavily, being a play on James Bond predominantly, but pokes fun at every spy movie whose villain plans to take over / destroy the world. A decent variety of minions requires some micro management to balance out what you require to carry out later missions in the game, ensuring you always have at least one of each alive so you don't have to go out and capture someone from the world to interrogate is a small quibble, but overall the system works well with an organic progression of minions along one of three trees: science, military, and social.There is not much immediate replay value in the game, however, after some time away it is always great to return to it and play a great strategy game in the manner of Dungeon Keeper mixed in with a little Theme Hospital as you try to keep your base safe and secure from enemy agents and keep it all running smoothly so that things don't back up and you end up with a bunch of unhappy, thieving, minions.A solid strategy game for any fan of the genre.

Posted: January 14, 2015
												A game so nice, I bought it twice.  That’s right, I can’t believe I did it either but yeah, my old copy was so badly scratched that I had little option but to take the full price and call it good.  This is just one of those games that I loved every moment of that I wanted to play it again and again.  Now that I have it on Steam, nothing will ever stop me from taking over the world!  Seriously though, it’s just way too fun to put down if you like to build efficient but deadly lairs for goody-two-shoes to try to break into.  Time to whip out my patented 'no hassle' wind tunnel security door rig...  It will never fail to punt everyone from the nosy tourist to the super sleuths’ from the nations of 'who cares' right out the door and hardly anyone ever dies!  This game is solid from the top to the bottom and the narration (via radio broadcasts) of your exploits abroad never stop being funny.  Seriously, when I blew up a state because of some country music star I didn’t like, it made me feel so good...  Or that time I shrunk the Eifel Tower, hilarious!  Did I mention you get to build your own secret (not really secret) base?  Better take some notes because every nation is going to be trying to find their way in and mess up your plans, or so they think.   Kill ‘em all or capture them so you can laugh in their faces just before the true torture begins!  You will never find a better game to make you feel like a true Evil Genius.

Posted: November 18, 2012
												I like Evil Genius because there simply aren't many games like it which I feel is a huge downer. There are awesome (but slightly lengthy) animations for EVERYTHING, tons of campy spy-thriller charm, and you get to play the bad guy which is another thing I like to see. Playing the villain. Okay, on occasion, not often, some villains are just terrible and poorly written.Micromangement is the name of the game as you juggle constructing a working evil lair while performing acts of infamy around the globe while keeping the lair safe from goody-goody-do-gooders-goody-two-shoes-long-gag. Chances are you'll screw up too if you don't know what you're doing. Especially later on. Not to mention that there are a couple glitches here and there that can potentially break the game. Go to Evil Planet (a old but still functioning website) and do some research there before making a run, it'll help. Also the game still runs perfectly well on Windows 7 (dunno about 8 yet) which is better then a few games on Steam that I can think of.Keep in mind that it is LONG though. It's all strategy gaming which means that things will be moving slowly, which is preferably since it only takes an instant to royally screw up and be forced to grab an earlier save file to make up for the huge losses (see: EVERY SINGLE SUPERAGENT APPEARANCE AT YOUR LAIR).Watch a bit on Youtube, see if it's your thing, maybe pick it up on sale (as small a chance as that would be).

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Want to rule the world like a James Bond Villain?  Want to laugh maniacally as the world falls at you feet?  Want to show those James Bond wanna bes who's the boss?  Want to spend more time building your evil lair than taking over the world?  Want to spend most of your time waiting for your money to build up?  Want to micromange every little detail when your minions should be doing the job themselves?  Then this game is for you!Ok in all seriousness even though this game has it's flaws I still think it's a great game.  It just has several big flaws that brings it down.  The waiting for money is my biggest issue.  You would think for a simulation game a fast forward button would be standard, not this one.  That's right you only have play and pause at your fingertips.  Well I hope you have something else to do whilst your waiting for that money to come in because there's little else to do whilst your waiting for the money.The micromanaging can get very monotanous very quickly.  You see since your evil activities are causing the world to send their "very best" spies to put a stop to your activities you have to keep an eye.  Minions won't automatically attack spies without you tagging them first.  Meaning your going to be randomly searching your base to see if any spies have landed and you really need to keep an eye out otherwise your beautiful base will be ruined in seconds (and trust me that is THE last thing you want unless you enjoy the waiting game).The basebuilding is the main part of the game.  Really this game should be called Evil Lair Architect.  Not that thats a bad thing the base building is very good.  It's the only simulation game I've played that allows you to plan out a building without it being built first.  This I like alot and other games would benefit from it, Simcity being one.  It's the optimazation of making your minions work hard and keeping spies out that make it a big draw for me however it's the waiting that makes it toturous.The minions themselves are divided into classes that do certain jobs.  You start of with a basic construction worker that do all the building for you that can then level up.  Scientists can do research for you to get new items (you can decide how they research the items but honestly this system is just luck based).  You have security minions that will beat up the spies.  You then have the social minions that can confuse spies into forgetting their mission (just like mp's).Taking over the world has little to it.  It's literly just a map.  Thats it.  You sends minions onto the map to complete missions or collect money for you.  Minions of different classes can do certain jobs better but honestly I would have appreciated a playable map similar to XCOM: Enemy Unkown.  Anything that makes the waiting more pleasant.If your graphics ♥♥♥♥♥ then I'm afraid this game will not satisfy you.  Granted it's an old game but even for it's age it doesn't look good (Rayman 2 was released 4 years before this one and looks just as good).The only thing that keeps this game up is it's charm and premise.  It's filled with humour (they interogate minions by dancing and putting them in a blender whats not to like?).  The premise itself is also interesting too.  Taking over the world who doesn't want to do that?  Honestly though these are the only things keeping it good for me along with the building mechanics.  If those aren't enough then I'm afraid this game is not for you.  If it is for you then I'd suggest waiting until this game goes on sale first.  Yes it is cheap to begin with at £7 but If your going to be dissappointed (and I wouldn't be surprised if you do) then get it cheap.

Posted: October 5, 2014
												This is seriously my favorite game of all time, and one of the best base-builders I've ever played.The theme is great and really fitting, and very reminiscent of a lot of super-villain based movies. The diversity of your minions is also awesome (in terms of minions, you've got the smart, the social, and the strong). The mechanics are really simplistic in a lot of ways but feel really deep - like the stats system in the game. It all works out to really reduce the amount of micro-management you typically have to do in a base-building game.The AI is something special in EG. In a lot of games, the AI just sort of knows where everything is and just rushes your face until either they're dead or you're dead. In EG, enemy agents that come to your island have literally no idea where anything is, where and traps are or anything at all really. They have to explore your island themselves, and they'll do their best to spot out any obvious traps you leave for them and break into every area they think is suspicious. It's also cool to sometimes see your own minions patrol around the base on their own when they're bored and have nothing else to do, taking the occasional smoke break (usually in the freezer, no idea why).EG's an amazing game, and I really wish they'd make a sequel instead of Facebook games and stuff. Maybe one day, but for now this is a great pick-up. It goes on sale all the time, and it's an absolute bargin for $2.50 when it's -75% off. Buy it.

Posted: October 5, 2014
												Oozing with super-spy style, this game is a playful take on base building and world domination.  Take over an island lair, recruit and train your minions, then use them to commit acts of infamy around the world.  You'll need to carefully balance accessibility for your minions and traps and defenses for the spies that are soon to come poking around, recruit henchmen and level them up, and finally make sure that your minions' needs are met so they don't lose loyalty to your organization!It's a ton of fun, and the only reason I can think of that it hasn't been done again is that the bar's set too high.  It has some quirks (you'll definitely need to find a guide to how research works), and there probably isn't enough in-game help to get you going, but it's one of my favorite strategy games ever.

Posted: October 1, 2014
												Superb. Base building, variety of rooms to create and equipment/objects to place in the rooms. Figuring out the most optimal layout or the most appealing base to the eye is one of the great aspects of this game. You have minons that work for you, think of it as like a bee colony, worker bees, soldiers, intelligent scientists and so on. Place traps in your corridors, art to motivate minions, cameras to spot intruders, fire extinguishers. The rooms that you create can also have security doors with varying levels of protection, at max level gaurds will stand in front of that room. Create rooms with doors or have an open mess hall or barracks, or any other room that pleases. Over time you will attract stronger Elite minions that have special abilities. Sending your minions to do missions on the world map will attract more attention to your island and that means you will have to expand your armed force or blend in as a tourist resort. Evil Genius has a quirky charm about it, an excellent game.

Posted: October 3, 2014
												This is pure nostalgia for me. I had this game as a kid and I still love it today. I remember reading on the box that it was inspired by Austin Powers. You start off on and island and have to build up a base inside a mountain. As you go on you start unlocking rooms and traps for the agents that are contantly trying to put a stop you your plans. There are alot of "job" that you have to pull off before you start to get noticed by the world. You send your minons out into the world to preform evil deeds that all take a certain amount of time to finish. Soon the Super Agents come after you and they cant be killed like normal agents. You have to find thier weakness first. After you move to the second island then you can start your doomsday project in the crater of volcano. You only get to control your Genius and henchmen but not your minons. Henchmen are your super-soldiers. They have 3 lifes and you start with only one, but you can recruit more later on. And for some reason your island has become a tourist attraction. You have to keep them occupied with hotels and lounges in order to keep them from wondering into your lair. There are three different type of minons: military, Science, and social. Each one branches into newer better types. This game is highly addictive once you start playing it, and it has a good sence of humor. I absolutely love every part of this game and I guaranty that you will love it too.

Posted: December 18, 2010
												Evil Genius is what happens when Dungeon Keeper and James Bond villains have a child together. You play, as the game's title says, an evil genius, bent on destroying the forces of good and conquering the whole world. You start off on a small island paradise, with only a handful of minions, 250,000 dollars, and a single henchmen. From there, your task is to build a complex base of operations into the mountainside,  complete with traps, training facilities, and more, while at the same time plundering riches and fighting off the constant intrusions from the forces of justice. Evil Genius manages to bring out the worst in all of us, and you'll be surprised to find yourself stalking the despised well-doers as they land on your little shred of land, eager to find out how they will meet your demise. And with ways ranging from bazooka-wielding Russians, to a complex set of bee-related traps, you'll find dozens of ways to amuse yourself with their death.

Posted: May 30, 2015
												The greatest Evil mastermind game ever made most likely.I played this game for hours and hours back when it was new.The game has a lot of humor and great characters.It has some very fun mechanics. Like building the ultimate trap rooms and watch as the Agents of the world tries to best your contraptions. And then do a truly evil laugh as they fail utterly.There is just something very special about being the Evil Genius and having minions to do your bidding in your quest for world domination.It's different and fun. And I have been waiting for Evil Genius 2 for years now. I really do hope somebody pics up this IP at some point and make a proper sequel.It's hard to express the joy of this game. But if you have ever wanted to be the Bond villain, then this game is your best bet.It does have a few flaws though. Quite a few actually.There is no widescreen support. But you can find a workaround for that if you google. "Evil Genius WSGF" The ui will be stretched though.Some of the mechanics are a bit annoying and requires more work then what should be necessary.There can also be a lot of down time while you wait for your minions to complete work orders. Or waiting for money to come in.There are more minor things that keeps irking me from time to time. But in the end the things that are good with the game far outweigh what is bad.If you are unsure about the game I would suggest watching some let's plays on youtube. I would also recommend not watching a whole lot of them if you want to avoid spoilers.There are some super agents that can only be defeated in a certain way. And some of the fun (and annoyance) in the game can come from defeating them. Until you can find that way to defeat them they will just keep coming back making your life hell.

Posted: October 5, 2014
												** I bought this game on GOG.com a long time ago, and only recently bought it on steam when it went on sale **~"Evil Genius" is truely unique and innovative, especially for a game released in 2004. I still question as to why a sequel/predecessor was never created, since i play through the game atleast once or twice a monthIt's Alot Like:Team Fortress 2 (Art Style)No One Lives Forever (Humor + Character Development)X-Com: UFO Defense (Base Building + Global Strategies + Missions)Black & White (Indirect Control of Units + Direct Control Of Heroes)Pros:-Addictive. Gameplay is simple yet intricate which yields a wide variety of possibilities-Characters/Units are amazingly colorful. Everything from animation to voice overs are drenched in -Easy to learn, difficult to masterCons:-Base Construction is slow at first due to Unit pathfinding problems.-Base & Unit Micromanagement gets tedious at higher levels because Unit pathfinding is mediocre. Units forget what theyre doing or stop what theyre doing all together randomly, which gets frusterating when defending your base from incoming spies, building large facilities, or sending alot of units out on large missions-Needs more depth/content. This is me nitpicking, because i know how old the game is and is something a sequel would address...but for me...the only reason i stop playing Evil Genius is because it simply leaves me with alot to be desired.Bottom Line: If you ever wanted to live out the most devious fantasies of Dr. Evil from Austin Powers, this is the game for you. Score:8.75/11

Posted: January 15, 2015
												A wonderful game that has aged well over the years. Unleash your inner Evil Mastermind as you build your island headquarters for your schemes and conduct missions all over the world against the forces of justice.A game I have put many hours into over the years when it first came out and glad to be playing it again, and while some of the graphics may not quite be up to standards of what some would expect today, it by no means looks horrific with the art style suiting the game perfectly. The music and menu screens add to the spy farce that this game plays to heavily, being a play on James Bond predominantly, but pokes fun at every spy movie whose villain plans to take over / destroy the world. A decent variety of minions requires some micro management to balance out what you require to carry out later missions in the game, ensuring you always have at least one of each alive so you don't have to go out and capture someone from the world to interrogate is a small quibble, but overall the system works well with an organic progression of minions along one of three trees: science, military, and social.There is not much immediate replay value in the game, however, after some time away it is always great to return to it and play a great strategy game in the manner of Dungeon Keeper mixed in with a little Theme Hospital as you try to keep your base safe and secure from enemy agents and keep it all running smoothly so that things don't back up and you end up with a bunch of unhappy, thieving, minions.A solid strategy game for any fan of the genre.

Posted: January 14, 2015
												A game so nice, I bought it twice.  That’s right, I can’t believe I did it either but yeah, my old copy was so badly scratched that I had little option but to take the full price and call it good.  This is just one of those games that I loved every moment of that I wanted to play it again and again.  Now that I have it on Steam, nothing will ever stop me from taking over the world!  Seriously though, it’s just way too fun to put down if you like to build efficient but deadly lairs for goody-two-shoes to try to break into.  Time to whip out my patented 'no hassle' wind tunnel security door rig...  It will never fail to punt everyone from the nosy tourist to the super sleuths’ from the nations of 'who cares' right out the door and hardly anyone ever dies!  This game is solid from the top to the bottom and the narration (via radio broadcasts) of your exploits abroad never stop being funny.  Seriously, when I blew up a state because of some country music star I didn’t like, it made me feel so good...  Or that time I shrunk the Eifel Tower, hilarious!  Did I mention you get to build your own secret (not really secret) base?  Better take some notes because every nation is going to be trying to find their way in and mess up your plans, or so they think.   Kill ‘em all or capture them so you can laugh in their faces just before the true torture begins!  You will never find a better game to make you feel like a true Evil Genius.

												It is difficult to compare this game to any other. The most satisfying aspect to me was the ability to design unique underground facilities. Players can also watch as their minions train, earning various specializations, and perform other mildly humorous tasks depending on their environment. One particularly annoying feature, however, is the overwhelming and terribly repetitive enemy agent infiltrations on your islands. The game is extremely fun, for a while, but if you're like me, the interminable qualities will weigh to such an extent that you will gradually lose interest until eventually feeling like playing the game is more of a nuisance than a privilege. I'd say it's worth the $10 cost as long as you can accept that its appeal might fade after a few solid days of gaming.

Posted: March 24, 2015
												Thoroughly enjoyed my first experience of this game. I had never heard of it before, but I have been looking for a game just like this for a long time. Although it is an old game (11+ years), this does not feel old in anyway, and if you told me it was released this year, I wouldn't be able to tell you otherwise without seeing the date.It is a great spin on the save the world nonsense that has been milked by companies for years (like the Quantum of Solace game that is just repackaged Goldeneye, (but lets not travel that rabbit hole)), and allows you to do the exact opposite, like setting traps for inspectors, interrogating prisoners, building a beautiful underground lair :) and just allowing yourself to be a generally bad guy.Once you get involved in building that beautiful lair and your nefarious empire it becomes extremely hard to stop (see that time played of 8 and a half hours, that was just on the first night). I consider replayability (its a word) to be one of the greatest measures of a game, especially on PC and this is one that will be in my library for the long haul, up there with Sins of a Solar Empire, Duke Nukem, AOE 2, C&C RA2, etc. You know those games where you may not play them for a while, but you always find yourself coming back to reinstall and play them.. well this is no doubt one of those.I am (like the rest of the community) hoping rebellion brings out a second at some stage, but to be honest, if that day never comes I don't think il be overly disappointed because this is such a great game and its aged like a fine wine.The other bonus to age is that prices drop, and even without a sale this bad boy is a bargain.

Posted: October 5, 2014
												This is seriously my favorite game of all time, and one of the best base-builders I've ever played.The theme is great and really fitting, and very reminiscent of a lot of super-villain based movies. The diversity of your minions is also awesome (in terms of minions, you've got the smart, the social, and the strong). The mechanics are really simplistic in a lot of ways but feel really deep - like the stats system in the game. It all works out to really reduce the amount of micro-management you typically have to do in a base-building game.The AI is something special in EG. In a lot of games, the AI just sort of knows where everything is and just rushes your face until either they're dead or you're dead. In EG, enemy agents that come to your island have literally no idea where anything is, where and traps are or anything at all really. They have to explore your island themselves, and they'll do their best to spot out any obvious traps you leave for them and break into every area they think is suspicious. It's also cool to sometimes see your own minions patrol around the base on their own when they're bored and have nothing else to do, taking the occasional smoke break (usually in the freezer, no idea why).EG's an amazing game, and I really wish they'd make a sequel instead of Facebook games and stuff. Maybe one day, but for now this is a great pick-up. It goes on sale all the time, and it's an absolute bargin for $2.50 when it's -75% off. Buy it.

Posted: October 5, 2014
												Oozing with super-spy style, this game is a playful take on base building and world domination.  Take over an island lair, recruit and train your minions, then use them to commit acts of infamy around the world.  You'll need to carefully balance accessibility for your minions and traps and defenses for the spies that are soon to come poking around, recruit henchmen and level them up, and finally make sure that your minions' needs are met so they don't lose loyalty to your organization!It's a ton of fun, and the only reason I can think of that it hasn't been done again is that the bar's set too high.  It has some quirks (you'll definitely need to find a guide to how research works), and there probably isn't enough in-game help to get you going, but it's one of my favorite strategy games ever.

Want to spend more time building your evil lair than taking over the world?  Want to spend most of your time waiting for your money to build up?  Want to micromange every little detail when your minions should be doing the job themselves?  Then this game is for you!Ok in all seriousness even though this game has it's flaws I still think it's a great game.  It just has several big flaws that brings it down.  The waiting for money is my biggest issue.  You would think for a simulation game a fast forward button would be standard, not this one.  That's right you only have play and pause at your fingertips.  Well I hope you have something else to do whilst your waiting for that money to come in because there's little else to do whilst your waiting for the money.The micromanaging can get very monotanous very quickly.  You see since your evil activities are causing the world to send their "very best" spies to put a stop to your activities you have to keep an eye.  Minions won't automatically attack spies without you tagging them first.  Meaning your going to be randomly searching your base to see if any spies have landed and you really need to keep an eye out otherwise your beautiful base will be ruined in seconds (and trust me that is THE last thing you want unless you enjoy the waiting game).The basebuilding is the main part of the game.  Really this game should be called Evil Lair Architect.  Not that thats a bad thing the base building is very good.  It's the only simulation game I've played that allows you to plan out a building without it being built first.  This I like alot and other games would benefit from it, Simcity being one.  It's the optimazation of making your minions work hard and keeping spies out that make it a big draw for me however it's the waiting that makes it toturous.The minions themselves are divided into classes that do certain jobs.  You start of with a basic construction worker that do all the building for you that can then level up.  Scientists can do research for you to get new items (you can decide how they research the items but honestly this system is just luck based).  You have security minions that will beat up the spies.  You then have the social minions that can confuse spies into forgetting their mission (just like mp's).Taking over the world has little to it.  It's literly just a map.  Thats it.  You sends minions onto the map to complete missions or collect money for you.  Minions of different classes can do certain jobs better but honestly I would have appreciated a playable map similar to XCOM: Enemy Unkown.  Anything that makes the waiting more pleasant.If your graphics ♥♥♥♥♥ then I'm afraid this game will not satisfy you.  Granted it's an old game but even for it's age it doesn't look good (Rayman 2 was released 4 years before this one and looks just as good).The only thing that keeps this game up is it's charm and premise.  It's filled with humour (they interogate minions by dancing and putting them in a blender whats not to like?).  The premise itself is also interesting too.  Taking over the world who doesn't want to do that?  Honestly though these are the only things keeping it good for me along with the building mechanics.  If those aren't enough then I'm afraid this game is not for you.  If it is for you then I'd suggest waiting until this game goes on sale first.  Yes it is cheap to begin with at £7 but If your going to be dissappointed (and I wouldn't be surprised if you do) then get it cheap.

The engine is great, the controls are great, you'll be playing it for about 30 hours, it's great.
