Posted: August 6, 2014
												First off, I love this game.  I've been playing it almost since it was first released and continue to come back to it time after time.  Granted... in that amount of time, I've never once reached the end.  Oh, I've gotten close.... so very very close.... only to end up falling victim to the bugs/glitches of the game, computer crashes, reformats, etc etc.The ability to play as a Evil Genius in a James Bond/Archer/Austin Powers type world is actually a great concept and really done well here.  You can build your own evil volcano lair while attempting to take over the world... I'll say it again, a evil volcano lair... Why I steeple my fingers just thinking about it.Building and maintaining your evil lair of evilness can be a blast and way more through provoking than it should be.  The same can be said for trap placement and layout for your hotel.There is enough humor to keep you tickled the whole time you play.  Just reading the mission text should give you at least a giggle and nothing can beat watching a super agent go through a series of traps you cleverly set for them.  Gaining henchmen is done rather well and they do have special abilities all their own.  Which can be helpful... unless you go with Red Ivan.  Why would anyone use a bazooka inside your bosses base? The options to torture those that have chosen wrongly to stand in your way of total victory are plentiful.  Seriously, take some time to look around for things to use.  You'll be surprised by the options... like the the messes blender.Having said all that... There are bugs... oh... is there ever and after a little while of playing you start to notice the lack of certain options.  Why can't I build a hallway thats one square wide?  Really?  Why?  Also... why can't I hide the entrance to my evil volcano lair?  Shouldn't that be like, I don't know, the first chapter in Evil Genius 101?  Could use one of those huts all camouflage like....This is one of those games that I pray gets a sequel that it deserves and one that isn't as buggy.  After all, it is a wonderful game with plenty of tongue in cheek humor.

Posted: June 19, 2011
												This game mixes base building perfectly with solid retrospective humour. Those of you familiar with old James Bond movies, with feel right at home with this games comedic foundations. The game will have you developing traps that open the floor to a deadly pit of saws one minute and then have you interrogating a prisioner with Micheal Jackson choreography the next. The game oozes with charm. Not only that, but the game offers a solid strategic challenge as well. You will find yourself having to keep track of both your base activies and your world domition tactics on the world map (Think total war, but with everything happening at once). This sense of micro-management will never leave you bored, or unatentive. The game always presents a obstacle for you to overcome, rather that be enemy agents trying to inflitrate your base, a power failure leaving your base vunerable or trying to keep pesky tourists from wondering into your evil lair the game consistently presents you with challenges, some difficult some not, and never at any point leaves you with nothing to do. Overall, this game is ranked in my Steam favourites. The game is genuinly funny and light hearted. It presents challenge with its gameplay, has a addictive formula to boot and is a hit for those who are fans of games like Dungeon(s) Keeper, Tropico and the like.

												I bought this the day it came out.  From an actual store, at full price -- I was that excited about it.You know Theme Hospital or ...well any of the Theme or Tycoon or similar games where you build a park/zoo/airport/factory/prison or whatever?  Take that, add a huge helping of James Bond (and any movie from that whole spy era) spoof, a lot of humor and plenty of developer love.You are building an underground evil lair, and you gotta make sure your minions have facilities to work, relax, train, rest, and research.  Of course you also need jails and interrogation machines for when you capture spies, and an elaborate trap system so agents and civilians don't get in, and don't forget room for a doomsday weapon.There are a few frustrating times when unfortunate timing results in the minion that was bringing an important item back from the helipad gets attacked by Jet Chan (lol!), and then others run to get the item to be slaughtered one by one. And as this game is kinda cartoon style the gameplay and animations are realy sadistic if you actually think of it ;D (No blood and gore though, but thats good, it would trhow this game out of its character.)And the graphics for a game this age, are very good. :)You are kinda limited to the campaign and theres only one island you can build your lair on. BUT in my opinion ? Totally worth €10.

Posted: March 13, 2015
												You are an Evil Genius, you want to control the world, and nothing will stop you.Build your base, recruit your henchmen and minions, keep it running, and cause havoc all over the globe.Let nothing stop your evil plan until you have complete and total world domination!Gameplay+ Strategy+ Build your very own base+ Control a base full of evil henchmen and minions+ Send them out to cause chaos in the world+ Choice of personal henchmen and Evil Genius+ Take over the world+ Three choices for world domination+ Collect artifacts from around the world+ Traps!+ Two islands to create your evil lair on+ Plenty of personal choice- Traps are difficult to get right, and often times you can end up hurting your own minions- Forces of Justice on your island are more of a nuisance than a threat- Until late game when they become very abundant and dangerous...The gameplay in Evil Genius is extremely fun, and rewarding. You are an Evil Genius, simple as that. Create your very own base, anyway you'd like it, fill it with a variety of different minions, all specialized in certain areas, to keep it running. Send them out on missions around the world to cause problems for the forces of good, and sometimes they’ll even come back with a nice priceless artifact for you to keep in your base. Protect your island from the do-gooders and dispose of their bodies in a nice, non-suspicious manner. Create traps to stop them, or simply just have them shot in the face. Torture persons of interest for information and to further your cause, with a variety items including, but not limited to, a mixing bowl, laser, brainwashing machine, and more. There are two islands to create your base on and three ways to take over the world and achieve total domination. Build traps for pesky investigators to find, chop them up, drop them in a piranha tank, or simply just scare them to death. There are so many ways to take over the world, and still so many annoying people snooping around my island ready to die.Audio/Visual+ Good graphics+ Nice audio+ Variety of minion/enemy appearances- Glitches in game cause audio and visual to mess up The graphics and audio in Evil Genius are quite impressive for its time. There is plenty of variety in the appearance of minions, henchman, and forces of justice. The island and base itself look pretty nice and are easily distinguishable from each other. However, since it is an older game, there are the occasional visual and audio glitches that can cause the screen to mess up or the sound to distort, but nothing game breaking.Overall/Quick ReviewEvil Genius is a well-done and perfectly executed strategy game revolving around you taking over the world. Graphics and audio are well done, with only the occasional glitch, but nothing game breaking. Gameplay itself is very fun, rewarding, and has plenty of variety and in henchmen, minions, enemies, traps, items, and rooms. Build your base anyway you want it, fill it with those you like, and take over the world anyway you want, each choice is personal.Choose your Evil Genius to get started on your path of domination! Create a base, recruit minions and henchmen to your cause, and make the world fall to their knees! Highly recommend! 9.5/10!

Posted: December 30, 2014
												It's not straightforward to recommend this game. On the gameplay front it does many things poorly, several in game factors collaborate to frustrate the player. Stupid minions running one by one into their deaths, while you can only watch their folly. Pesky invulnerable super agents destroying your base. Traps being somewhat poorly balanced. There's no way to turn off just the announcer's warnings - you'd have to turn off all sounds. The pacing is very slow at the beginning. There are only two islands on which to construct your bases - no random maps, no skirmish mode. Specialist science minions and social minions have little to do. Acts of infamy provide little tangible benefit...How can the game be any good then?Because of the things it does good, it does really well. And there are very few games similar to this (Dungeon Keeper being the closest). It's all style over substance. The art direction, themes and music (particularly title soundtracks) are just spot on and so perfectly captures the idea of playing Bond-film like villain, constructing a secret base in order to take over the world! The animations are superbly done, cartoony, but appropriately so. Thus even though the game is 10 years old, it still manages to look alright. If the theme and management style in any way appeals to you give this game a try, but if you enjoyed Dungeon Keeper this is almost a must-play in my opinion.

Posted: January 15, 2015
												A wonderful game that has aged well over the years. Unleash your inner Evil Mastermind as you build your island headquarters for your schemes and conduct missions all over the world against the forces of justice.A game I have put many hours into over the years when it first came out and glad to be playing it again, and while some of the graphics may not quite be up to standards of what some would expect today, it by no means looks horrific with the art style suiting the game perfectly. The music and menu screens add to the spy farce that this game plays to heavily, being a play on James Bond predominantly, but pokes fun at every spy movie whose villain plans to take over / destroy the world. A decent variety of minions requires some micro management to balance out what you require to carry out later missions in the game, ensuring you always have at least one of each alive so you don't have to go out and capture someone from the world to interrogate is a small quibble, but overall the system works well with an organic progression of minions along one of three trees: science, military, and social.There is not much immediate replay value in the game, however, after some time away it is always great to return to it and play a great strategy game in the manner of Dungeon Keeper mixed in with a little Theme Hospital as you try to keep your base safe and secure from enemy agents and keep it all running smoothly so that things don't back up and you end up with a bunch of unhappy, thieving, minions.A solid strategy game for any fan of the genre.

Posted: March 24, 2015
												Thoroughly enjoyed my first experience of this game. I had never heard of it before, but I have been looking for a game just like this for a long time. Although it is an old game (11+ years), this does not feel old in anyway, and if you told me it was released this year, I wouldn't be able to tell you otherwise without seeing the date.It is a great spin on the save the world nonsense that has been milked by companies for years (like the Quantum of Solace game that is just repackaged Goldeneye, (but lets not travel that rabbit hole)), and allows you to do the exact opposite, like setting traps for inspectors, interrogating prisoners, building a beautiful underground lair :) and just allowing yourself to be a generally bad guy.Once you get involved in building that beautiful lair and your nefarious empire it becomes extremely hard to stop (see that time played of 8 and a half hours, that was just on the first night). I consider replayability (its a word) to be one of the greatest measures of a game, especially on PC and this is one that will be in my library for the long haul, up there with Sins of a Solar Empire, Duke Nukem, AOE 2, C&C RA2, etc. You know those games where you may not play them for a while, but you always find yourself coming back to reinstall and play them.. well this is no doubt one of those.I am (like the rest of the community) hoping rebellion brings out a second at some stage, but to be honest, if that day never comes I don't think il be overly disappointed because this is such a great game and its aged like a fine wine.The other bonus to age is that prices drop, and even without a sale this bad boy is a bargain.

Posted: December 22, 2015
												Probably my all time favorite game ever. I may have more hours on other games, but there is nothing else I come back to year after year. Mind you the hours shown are the amount I have on steam. I originally had the game on disk... twice before buying it on steam so who knows how many hours I really have.About the game, you can read other peoples reviews for more depth, but what brings me back is the pure joy of building your base, especially once you get to the (spoilers) second island when you have a large cash reserve and most of the rooms unlocked.Of course it's not all about the base building, the game itself is about completing objectives on the world map by sending out henchmen. As you progress you will need more advanced henchmen which you train in your base.And what classic super villain situation is complete with without meddling do gooders and of course special agents who will travel to your island, requiring you to distract or eliminate them before they discover evidence of your nefarious plots. One way to combat them is to build traps which can be as simple as a single piranha tank to a network of traps that blows, chops then burns agents foolish enough to enter your base.The game graphics aren't HD or anything, but they still look quite good, it kind of fits in with the game itself actually as it is themed as a classic super villain vs world type of deal.I cannot recommend this game enough, especially since these days it is priced at only $10.Oh and after you've played few a few times, I would look into how to increase the minion cap, I upped mine to 200, It is very nice to have way more top level minions as well as making the base feel more alive.

Posted: February 2, 2016
What I liked about the game:1. I loved the satirical elements that mocked spies specifically from spy movies.2. I liked the storyline.What I disliked about the game:1. A tad slow at times where you are trying to generate cash, sometimes you are brainlessly checking to make sure no agents get into the inner part of your base.2. The different Evil Geniuses should affect the gameplay more than just additive bonuses.3. You might not get a bunch of hours on this game, however it is still fun to come back and replay the game from time to time.Why I would recommend this game:1. It is easy to run on laptops.2. It is a fun build-your-own-base type of game.3. With the time I have played it, I have never run into any glitches.4. I would recommend it to any person who has seen a couple spy movies to appreciate the satire.5. If you like games like Sim City or Prison Archetect definitely pick this one up :-)6. You get to be a villan.Why I would not recommend this game: (to some people)1. Patience is needed when playing this game. (World Domination isn't as easy as clicking your mouse once)2. If you hate spy movies, or more specifically, the villans in spy movies then you don't want this game.Overall, I would recommend this game. If you don't think you would like it, give it a try!

Posted: April 3, 2016
												One of my favorite games of all time. I've put in hundreds of hours into this game outside of the Steam version. Developing an efficient base, leveling up your sidekicks, and researching new items for your lair is rewarding. It's odd how much fun watching scientist study things in your base and then having a breakthrough so you can start research on new traps, doors, and other items. I think the weakest part of the game is the combat. Sometimes the Super Agents come in and really set your base back and there's nothing you can do. Also I never really got into the traps. I'm not going to say they don't work because maybe I wasn't creative enough with the set up of the traps, but they didn't seem effective. If you love base building sims this is a must buy.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												I missed this game when it first released but had always wanted to give it a go as I heard it was similar to Dungeon Keeper, a much loved game from my early PC gaming days. After seeing it had launched on Steam for a modest price I snagged a copy and am pleasantly surprised by how in depth this hidden gem is, in some ways I actually prefer it to Dungeon Keeper. The interesting thing about this villainous base builder is that rather than building small lairs and moving from level to level, you only have two islands to build on, one that you access from the start and another that unlocks halfway through. This allows you to expand your HQ over time and it's a rewarding experience to finally see your underground criminal empire begin to flourish. You also have access to a world map screen that allows you to influence the world outside of your base by sending your henchmen to commit crimes or perform espionage in various countries which brings in gold, specialist units and ups your notoriety. But beware, the more influential you become, the more secret agents the governments of the world will send to your island to unravel your insidious schemes. It should be noted that the game's theme is heavily influenced by 60s spy serials and it carries this off with a comedic tone reminiscent of the Austin Powers movies, which I rather enjoyed.If you're a fan of Dungeon Keeper or looking to get into to the whole base building, overlord style strategy genre, I highly recommend this game. It's a great time sink and it's easy to lose a few hours twiddling your evil moustache and plotting world domination. Just be sure to watch out for that pesky super agent John Steele.

Posted: May 30, 2015
												The greatest Evil mastermind game ever made most likely.I played this game for hours and hours back when it was new.The game has a lot of humor and great characters.It has some very fun mechanics. Like building the ultimate trap rooms and watch as the Agents of the world tries to best your contraptions. And then do a truly evil laugh as they fail utterly.There is just something very special about being the Evil Genius and having minions to do your bidding in your quest for world domination.It's different and fun. And I have been waiting for Evil Genius 2 for years now. I really do hope somebody pics up this IP at some point and make a proper sequel.It's hard to express the joy of this game. But if you have ever wanted to be the Bond villain, then this game is your best bet.It does have a few flaws though. Quite a few actually.There is no widescreen support. But you can find a workaround for that if you google. "Evil Genius WSGF" The ui will be stretched though.Some of the mechanics are a bit annoying and requires more work then what should be necessary.There can also be a lot of down time while you wait for your minions to complete work orders. Or waiting for money to come in.There are more minor things that keeps irking me from time to time. But in the end the things that are good with the game far outweigh what is bad.If you are unsure about the game I would suggest watching some let's plays on youtube. I would also recommend not watching a whole lot of them if you want to avoid spoilers.There are some super agents that can only be defeated in a certain way. And some of the fun (and annoyance) in the game can come from defeating them. Until you can find that way to defeat them they will just keep coming back making your life hell.

												Definently buy this game especially when it is on sale. I dont have very many hours in this game yet but it helped me realize that i am a psychopath and i love that. First off you start out on a big canvas to make your very own evil base. I would strongly suggest doing the tutorial as this game can be a bit confusing. I know what you are thinking. What is the point of building an evil base on an abandoned island. Well my friend let me start off by saying that in your evil base you have the power to capture maids and starve them to death. Still doesnt sound like fun? How about this, you can build a large variety of hilarious traps such as gas chambers and wind machines that you can put anywhere in your base. Secret spies from around the world will try to kill your "boss" and instead of sending my minions/bodyguards out to kill them i usually just let them into my base to watch them land in one of my many traps. This game is a masterpiece and the graphics are pretty good, it amazes me it was made so long ago.Judgement 9/10 Would buy again.

Posted: January 17, 2016
												First off:BE CAREFUL WHERE YOU PLACE YOUR CONFERENCE TABLEIf you move or delete it at any point after building it but before Objective 2 is totally complete, you'll glitch your savegame and be unable to proceed.  That being said, this game is phenomenal.  Pretty forgiving early on, with a difficulty arc both graceful and satisfying that really gets much tougher later.  The graphics are of course dated, but as is the hallmark of many truly great games it doesn't matter.  The fun comes from the game, and the graphics are there to help you keep track.    It is often compared to the Dungeoun Keeper series, which is fair.  I played me some Dungeon Keeper 2 back in the day, when mice had balls and input devices were not even hot-swappable, let alone wireless.  Despite the relative technological desolation of those dark ages, I remember that being a pretty awesome game.  Still, I cannot adequately describe how much happier I am to be a sinister plotting megalomaniac bent on world domination. Many of the reviews here already break the game down by pros and cons, etc, so I'm just going to say highly recommended, and even when not on sale it's pretty cheap.  Take a spiritual journey to 2004 with Elixir Studios and get in touch with your inner despicable villian.      Extra Endorsement: I experienced the glitch with the conference table on my very first playthrough of the game, and found out about it on the internet after being stuck for hours unable to complete Objective 2.  20ish hours into the game, my whole save became worthless.  Without any hesitation, I calmly opened the menu and clicked "New Game".  For me, that means this game = digital crack.

Posted: November 28, 2016
												This is hands-down my favorite game of all time.I remembering discovering this game a few years after it was released and I was (and still am) blown away by the unique comedy, the beautifully artistic styling, that jazzy soundtrack, the amazing gameplay, just everything!This is one of those games that is worth it at ANY price. You will not be disappointed if you're a fan of base building games. Even if you're not a fan of base building games, I'm sure you'll really appreciate the level of artistic mastery (visual and auditory) in this game.Steam says I've only poured 60 some hours into this game, but I've also owned this game from before Steam. Added all together, I'd honestly put my total hours in the thousands since the game was first released.When I make millions of my startup, I fully intend to fund Evil Genius 2. I don't care if it loses money; just the sheer joy of releasing Evil Genius and making it even better would be worth it.TLDR BUY THIS GAME NO MATTER THE PRICE; You will not be disappointed.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												This game has it's flaws, there's no denying that.  The arbitrary headcount limit (fortunately fixable with mods).  The lack of direct control over your minions (and the baffling decisions they sometimes make as a result).  The way the game forces you to make yourself incredibly vulnerable halfway through, leaving you scrambling to get everything secure again.But god damn, it pulls it off with so much style that it makes you forget all of that.  When you're designing your fiendish lair, deciding where best to put a miniaturised Eiffel Tower, or using a centrifuge to interrogate secret agents, you no longer care about the problems.It's far from perfect.  But I don't regret a minute I spent playing it.

Posted: February 25, 2015
												Right out of the 'box' so to speak, i like the game and the feel. Mindless minions runing around doing my bidding? YES PLEASE! In order to get more advanced minions, you have to first kidnap someone, and then torture the info from them... PERFECT!  You play as 1 of 3 'types' of evil geniuses, i beleive this only effects your 'power' over minionsYou are given an initial island base with limited interior build space.You start with workers, and a body guard. Ideally, you simply go to the world map and either commit continuous crime in an area, or commit acts of imfamy for trophies and or research advancement;Pros -The 'henchman' advancment system is fairly involving and can be very entertainingYou BUILD your base, and design it however you like with mostly very few hinderances.YOU decide how your security systems work, i discovered later that it is VERY indepth for how simple the game seems.minion happiness and training keeps you involvedd in the progrsssion of your minions, though to an extent it is fairly automated.For intruders there is a relitivey simple tagging  system, mostly capture or kill, so that your minions know what to do when they get to the 'tagged' individualcons--Ima be brutally honest.. the ai in this game is garbage. Due to this 1 hinderance, after a certain point you  cant even 'leave' your base for wave after wave of 'invaders' you you litterally have to micro manage your security system to take care of.Most tagged indivuduals can litterally walk right in the front door, with no reaction from security system.AI defences are so weak that non 'elite' units can take out several sentry drones without any damage at all.If you have too many minions passing through traps, the traps trigger (yes, on your own minions)Superagents were a fun gimmick but after a while they become an annoying PITA as they tunnel in to your base and blow up several rooms worth of stuff. annd sadly, the FIRE ALARM works faster than security, as security rarely if ever responds...Due to the bugged ai and trap system, TAGGED SuperAgents can walk right in the front door, through traps, cameras, guard stations, everything.this game is old, but very fun, id still recomend it.really wish someone would make a new one.***Edited for some spelling Errors******Updated  For Content***

Posted: November 18, 2012
												I like Evil Genius because there simply aren't many games like it which I feel is a huge downer. There are awesome (but slightly lengthy) animations for EVERYTHING, tons of campy spy-thriller charm, and you get to play the bad guy which is another thing I like to see. Playing the villain. Okay, on occasion, not often, some villains are just terrible and poorly written.Micromangement is the name of the game as you juggle constructing a working evil lair while performing acts of infamy around the globe while keeping the lair safe from goody-goody-do-gooders-goody-two-shoes-long-gag. Chances are you'll screw up too if you don't know what you're doing. Especially later on. Not to mention that there are a couple glitches here and there that can potentially break the game. Go to Evil Planet (a old but still functioning website) and do some research there before making a run, it'll help. Also the game still runs perfectly well on Windows 7 (dunno about 8 yet) which is better then a few games on Steam that I can think of.Keep in mind that it is LONG though. It's all strategy gaming which means that things will be moving slowly, which is preferably since it only takes an instant to royally screw up and be forced to grab an earlier save file to make up for the huge losses (see: EVERY SINGLE SUPERAGENT APPEARANCE AT YOUR LAIR).Watch a bit on Youtube, see if it's your thing, maybe pick it up on sale (as small a chance as that would be).

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Want to rule the world like a James Bond Villain?  Want to laugh maniacally as the world falls at you feet?  Want to show those James Bond wanna bes who's the boss?  Want to spend more time building your evil lair than taking over the world?  Want to spend most of your time waiting for your money to build up?  Want to micromange every little detail when your minions should be doing the job themselves?  Then this game is for you!Ok in all seriousness even though this game has it's flaws I still think it's a great game.  It just has several big flaws that brings it down.  The waiting for money is my biggest issue.  You would think for a simulation game a fast forward button would be standard, not this one.  That's right you only have play and pause at your fingertips.  Well I hope you have something else to do whilst your waiting for that money to come in because there's little else to do whilst your waiting for the money.The micromanaging can get very monotanous very quickly.  You see since your evil activities are causing the world to send their "very best" spies to put a stop to your activities you have to keep an eye.  Minions won't automatically attack spies without you tagging them first.  Meaning your going to be randomly searching your base to see if any spies have landed and you really need to keep an eye out otherwise your beautiful base will be ruined in seconds (and trust me that is THE last thing you want unless you enjoy the waiting game).The basebuilding is the main part of the game.  Really this game should be called Evil Lair Architect.  Not that thats a bad thing the base building is very good.  It's the only simulation game I've played that allows you to plan out a building without it being built first.  This I like alot and other games would benefit from it, Simcity being one.  It's the optimazation of making your minions work hard and keeping spies out that make it a big draw for me however it's the waiting that makes it toturous.The minions themselves are divided into classes that do certain jobs.  You start of with a basic construction worker that do all the building for you that can then level up.  Scientists can do research for you to get new items (you can decide how they research the items but honestly this system is just luck based).  You have security minions that will beat up the spies.  You then have the social minions that can confuse spies into forgetting their mission (just like mp's).Taking over the world has little to it.  It's literly just a map.  Thats it.  You sends minions onto the map to complete missions or collect money for you.  Minions of different classes can do certain jobs better but honestly I would have appreciated a playable map similar to XCOM: Enemy Unkown.  Anything that makes the waiting more pleasant.If your graphics ♥♥♥♥♥ then I'm afraid this game will not satisfy you.  Granted it's an old game but even for it's age it doesn't look good (Rayman 2 was released 4 years before this one and looks just as good).The only thing that keeps this game up is it's charm and premise.  It's filled with humour (they interogate minions by dancing and putting them in a blender whats not to like?).  The premise itself is also interesting too.  Taking over the world who doesn't want to do that?  Honestly though these are the only things keeping it good for me along with the building mechanics.  If those aren't enough then I'm afraid this game is not for you.  If it is for you then I'd suggest waiting until this game goes on sale first.  Yes it is cheap to begin with at £7 but If your going to be dissappointed (and I wouldn't be surprised if you do) then get it cheap.

Posted: June 26, 2015
												For all its bugs and waiting around for things to happen, this game is one of my firm favourites.Following in the footsteps of Dungeon Keeper, but putting forth its own charming brand of sinister fun, Evil Genius kept me playing for hours and still pulls me back.Others have tried to replicate that playful darkness that was DK, and Evil Genius is the closest I've seen. To be frank, the hotels are too much trouble to be worth it. Its much more fun to spend hours nuancing a lovely complex trap and chuckling devilishly to yourself. Only thing missing is a swivel chair and a white haired cat.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												It's like Dungeon Master, James Bond (villain) style. There's nothing more satisfying than stealing the worlds treasures and putting them on display in your base to boost your worker's mood. If that doesn't tickle your fancy you can set up elaborate traps to defeat INTERPOL agents or even the games James Bond-type secret agents. All the while you need to keep hapless tourists busy in hotels and manage your criminal empire on the world map to earn cash and complete missions (wihout brining down too much heat on yourself). Helping you in your tasks are a number of unique henchmen like a rogue Samurai or a crazy Nanny who earn experience to level up and unlock special attacks. There are a few small annoying things about the game which could be fixed in a great sequel but until I get my doomsday device working to force that to happen this is worth playing the in the meantime.

Posted: April 3, 2016
												One of my favorite games of all time. I've put in hundreds of hours into this game outside of the Steam version. Developing an efficient base, leveling up your sidekicks, and researching new items for your lair is rewarding. It's odd how much fun watching scientist study things in your base and then having a breakthrough so you can start research on new traps, doors, and other items. I think the weakest part of the game is the combat. Sometimes the Super Agents come in and really set your base back and there's nothing you can do. Also I never really got into the traps. I'm not going to say they don't work because maybe I wasn't creative enough with the set up of the traps, but they didn't seem effective. If you love base building sims this is a must buy.

Is that cool or what?Then we need to recruit some faithfull minions. Yes! We are head of evil organisation so we need someone to do a dirty work for us.Then we got a lot of objectives to accomplish- from kidnapping, to stealing art, building secret super weapons... name it.Yeah- graphic is old, but still good.Game has tons of humor.Music & sounds are great.This is fun, good game.If you like spy movies and games like dungeon keeper- BUY IT.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												This game has it's flaws, there's no denying that.  The arbitrary headcount limit (fortunately fixable with mods).  The lack of direct control over your minions (and the baffling decisions they sometimes make as a result).  The way the game forces you to make yourself incredibly vulnerable halfway through, leaving you scrambling to get everything secure again.But god damn, it pulls it off with so much style that it makes you forget all of that.  When you're designing your fiendish lair, deciding where best to put a miniaturised Eiffel Tower, or using a centrifuge to interrogate secret agents, you no longer care about the problems.It's far from perfect.  But I don't regret a minute I spent playing it.

												This is hands-down my favorite game of all time.I remembering discovering this game a few years after it was released and I was (and still am) blown away by the unique comedy, the beautifully artistic styling, that jazzy soundtrack, the amazing gameplay, just everything!This is one of those games that is worth it at ANY price. You will not be disappointed if you're a fan of base building games. Even if you're not a fan of base building games, I'm sure you'll really appreciate the level of artistic mastery (visual and auditory) in this game.Steam says I've only poured 60 some hours into this game, but I've also owned this game from before Steam. Added all together, I'd honestly put my total hours in the thousands since the game was first released.When I make millions of my startup, I fully intend to fund Evil Genius 2. I don't care if it loses money; just the sheer joy of releasing Evil Genius and making it even better would be worth it.TLDR BUY THIS GAME NO MATTER THE PRICE; You will not be disappointed.
